params.text:
B2: Human Resources

Onboarding 1 –
Presenting the Workplace

Facilitating a Smooth Integration of Employees
Module Introduction

This module will equip you with the essential language and skills to confidently and effectively onboard new employees. 
In this module, you will:

• Expand your vocabulary related to company policies, roles, responsibilities, and workplace culture.
  • Practice delivering clear and engaging presentations to help new employees understand their roles and integrate smoothly into the company.
  • Develop effective strategies for addressing new hires' questions and ensuring they align with the company culture.
By the end of this module, you will be able to conduct successful onboarding sessions that set new employees up for success and contribute to a positive and productive work environment.
Master Vocabulary - Key Vocabulary

params.taskDescription: Match the words to their definitions to learn useful phrases for employee onboarding:
params.resetDropDescription: Are you sure you want to reset this drop zone?
params.a11yCheck: Check the answers. The responses will be marked as correct, incorrect, or unanswered.
params.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
params.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.
params.textField:
*Organizational Chart (Org Chart)*: A visual representation of a company's structure, showing the relationships between different departments, positions, and employees. It clarifies reporting lines and helps new hires understand where they fit within the larger organization.
*Job Description:* A formal document that outlines the specific tasks, responsibilities, and required skills for a particular role. It provides a clear understanding of what is expected of the new employee.
*Performance Expectations:* The specific goals and standards of performance that are expected of an employee in their role. These can include targets, deadlines, and quality standards. Clearly communicating these helps new hires understand how their performance will be evaluated.

params.text: Master Vocabulary - Key Vocabulary

params.taskDescription: Match the words to their definitions to learn useful phrases for employee onboarding:
params.resetDropDescription: Are you sure you want to reset this drop zone?
params.a11yCheck: Check the answers. The responses will be marked as correct, incorrect, or unanswered.
params.a11yShowSolution: Show the solution. The task will be marked with its correct solution.
params.a11yRetry: Retry the task. Reset all responses and start the task over again.
params.textField:
*Code of Conduct:* A set of rules and guidelines outlining acceptable behavior within a company. It covers areas such as ethics, professionalism, and workplace conduct. It's crucial for new hires to understand the company's expectations regarding behavior.
*Benefits Package:* The complete set of benefits offered to employees in addition to their salary. This often includes health insurance, retirement plans, paid time off, and other perks. Explaining the benefits package is a key part of onboarding.
*Probationary Period:* A trial period at the beginning of employment during which the employee's performance and suitability for the role are evaluated. It's important for new hires to understand the length and purpose of the probationary period.

params.text: Master Vocabulary - Forum & Quiz

You are on an online forum where HR managers are discussing policies and onboarding in their company.
Please read the posts and answer the questions below:

Xian Lee:
(HR Manager at
Grant Consulting)

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What does Yulia Benzov emphasize as important during onboarding at Strickland Food Group?
answers:
Reinforcing company values and teamwork.

Strict adherence to dress code policies. 

Completing all paperwork efficiently.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What is a key element of the onboarding process at Grant Consulting, according to Xian Lee?
answers:
Providing new hires with a comprehensive handbook. 

Focusing solely on technical skills training. 

Assigning new hires to independent projects immediately.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Ahmed Lidneb highlight as crucial during onboarding at Warner Aerospace?
answers:
Setting clear expectations and explaining job roles. 

Minimizing interaction to avoid overwhelming new hires. 

Focusing primarily on the company's history and achievements.

params.text: "Clear communication is key to successful onboarding. We provide new hires with a comprehensive handbook outlining all company policies, from dress code to code of conduct. We also assign a buddy to each new employee to answer questions and provide support during their first few weeks."

"At Strickland Food Group, we emphasize our values during onboarding. We want new hires to understand our commitment to quality, sustainability, and teamwork from day one. We use interactive sessions and team-building activities to reinforce these values and help new employees integrate quickly."

"We believe in setting clear expectations from the start. During onboarding, we thoroughly explain job descriptions, performance expectations, and opportunities for professional development. We also encourage new hires to ask questions and actively participate in the onboarding process."

Ahmed Lidneb:
(HR Manager at
Warner Aerospace)

Yulia Benzov:
(HR Manager at
Strickland Food Group)
Ahmed Lidneb – HR Manager at Warner Aerospace – is discussing the company Org Chart with a new engineer – Fatime Diouf. Please listen to the conversation and answer the questions.

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Dialogue Text:

Ahmed Lidneb: Welcome to Warner Aerospace, Fatima! I'm so glad to have you on the team. One of the first things we'll do is walk through the organizational chart. This will give you a clear picture of how the company is structured and where you fit in.

Fatima Diouf: Thank you, Ahmed. I appreciate that. It can be a bit confusing at first.

Ahmed Lidneb: Absolutely. Here's the org chart. At the very top, we have our CEO, James Warner. He oversees the entire company and sets the overall strategic direction.

Fatima Diouf: Okay, that makes sense.

Ahmed Lidneb: Reporting directly to Mr. Warner are the heads of our major divisions. We have the Engineering Division, the Manufacturing Division, the Sales and Marketing Division, and the Finance Division. Each of these divisions is led by a Vice President.

Fatima Diouf: And I'm in the Engineering Division, correct?

Ahmed Lidneb: Exactly. You're part of the Engineering Division, which is headed by Sarah Chen, our VP of Engineering. Within the Engineering Division, we have several departments, such as Research and Development, Design, and Testing. You'll be working in the Design Department.

Fatima Diouf: I see. So, I report to the Design Department Manager?

Ahmed Lidneb: Precisely. The Design Department Manager for your team is David Miller. He'll be your direct supervisor. He'll be your go-to person for day-to-day tasks, performance reviews, and any questions you might have.

Fatima Diouf: That's helpful. And the other names on the chart, like Project Leads and Senior Engineers?

Ahmed Lidneb: Those are the different roles within the Design Department. You'll be working alongside other engineers, some of whom are more senior and may lead specific projects. We'll introduce you to your team later today.

Fatima Diouf: Great! This chart makes it much clearer. Thanks for explaining it, Ahmed.

Ahmed Lidneb: You're very welcome, Fatima. Understanding the org chart is a crucial first step in getting acclimated to the company. Don't hesitate to ask if you have any further questions as you get settled in.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: Who is the CEO of Warner Aerospace?
answers:
James Warner 

Sarah Chen 

David Miller

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: Which division will Fatima Diouf be working in?
answers:
Engineering Division 

Manufacturing Division

Sales and Marketing Division

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Who is Fatima Diouf's direct supervisor?
answers:
David Miller 

Sarah Chen 

James Warner

Xian Lee is meeting with a new consultant – Rakesh Chowdry – to discuss his onboarding. Please listen to the conversation and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Master Vocabulary – Meeting & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

Xian Lee: Welcome to Grant Consulting, Rakesh! It's great to finally have you here. I'm Xian Lee, and I'll be guiding you through the onboarding process.

Rakesh Chowdry: Thank you, Xian. I'm excited to get started.

Xian Lee: I'm sure you are! Onboarding at Grant Consulting is designed to make your transition as smooth as possible. It's a two-week program that covers everything from company policies and benefits to introductions to your team and project assignments.

Rakesh Chowdry: That sounds comprehensive. What can I expect in my first week?

Xian Lee: Your first week will focus on getting you acquainted with the company culture and your team. Today, we'll complete all the necessary paperwork, including your employment contract and benefits enrollment. We'll also give you a tour of the office and introduce you to your team members.

Rakesh Chowdry: Great. I'm looking forward to meeting everyone.

Xian Lee: Tomorrow, we'll dive into the company's code of conduct, IT policies, and security procedures. It's important that you understand these guidelines from the beginning. We'll also discuss our performance expectations and how your performance will be evaluated.

Rakesh Chowdry: That's helpful. Will I be assigned to a project right away?

Xian Lee: Not immediately. For the rest of the week, you'll be shadowing a senior consultant on a current project. This will give you a chance to observe how we work and learn the ropes before taking on your own assignments. It's a great way to learn by doing and ask questions in a real-world context.

Rakesh Chowdry: That sounds like a good way to get integrated into the team.

Xian Lee: Absolutely. We also have several training sessions scheduled throughout the week to familiarize you with our internal systems and software. We want to make sure you have all the tools you need to succeed.

Rakesh Chowdry: That's excellent. I appreciate the structured approach.

Xian Lee: We believe in setting our new hires up for success. We'll check in with you regularly throughout your first two weeks to answer any questions and address any concerns you might have. We want to ensure you feel comfortable and supported as you begin your career at Grant Consulting.

Rakesh Chowdry: Thank you. This all sounds very well-organized. I'm eager to start contributing.

Xian Lee: We're equally eager to have you. Let's head to my office and get started with the paperwork.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: How long is the onboarding program at Grant Consulting?
answers:
Two weeks

One week 

One month 

Three months

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What will Rakesh Chowdry be doing for the rest of his first week?
answers:
Shadowing a senior consultant 

Leading a new project

Attending client meetings 

Completing independent research

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What is one of the things Rakesh Chowdry will do on his first day?
answers:
Complete paperwork and get a tour of the office.

Begin working on a client project.

Meet with the CEO. 

Lead a training session for other new hires.

params.text:
Rakesh Chowdry:
(New Consultant at
Grant Consulting)

Xian Lee:
(HR Manager at
Grant Consulting)
Master Vocabulary - What Would You Do?
What would you do in the following situations? Please answer the following questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: You are onboarding a new employee, and they seem very nervous and quiet. What would you do?
answers:
Acknowledge their nervousness, offer reassurance, and try to engage them in conversation about their interests or previous experiences. 

Focus on getting through the paperwork quickly to minimize their discomfort. 

Assume they just need time to adjust and continue with the onboarding process as planned.

choices.question: Question 2 of 4: You are explaining the company's code of conduct, and the new employee asks a challenging question about a specific policy that seems unclear. What would you do?
answers:
Acknowledge the employee's valid question, admit the policy could be clearer, and offer to follow up with HR or legal to get a definitive answer. 

Dismiss the question, stating that all policies are clearly explained in the handbook. 

Try to interpret the policy yourself, even if you're not entirely sure of the correct interpretation.

choices.question: Question 3 of 4: You are giving a new employee a tour of the office, and you realize you've forgotten to introduce them to a key team member. What would you do?
answers:
Apologize for the oversight, explain the importance of the team member's role, and make sure to connect them as soon as possible. 

Skip the introduction and continue with the tour, hoping the employee won't notice. 

Tell the employee they'll meet the team member later and continue with the tour as planned.

choices.question: Question 4 of 4: A new employee is struggling to understand the company's performance management system. What would you do?
answers:
Offer to schedule a separate meeting to walk them through the system step-by-step, answering any questions they have.

Tell them to read the employee handbook again, as all the information is there. 

Tell them they'll figure it out eventually and not to worry about it too much.

params.text: Please listen to an interview on a HR podcast between a journalist and Yulia Benzov – HR Manager at Strickland Food Group and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Delivering Presentations – Interview & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

Journalist: Ms. Benzov, thank you for speaking with us today. Onboarding new employees is crucial for their success and integration into a company. What are some key tips for delivering engaging presentations during the onboarding process?

Yulia Benzov: It's a pleasure to be here. Engaging presentations are essential for making new hires feel welcome and informed. My first tip is to keep it concise and focused. New employees are bombarded with information, so avoid overwhelming them. Stick to the most important points and break down complex topics into smaller, digestible chunks.

Journalist: That makes sense. What else can make a presentation more engaging?

Yulia Benzov: Visual aids are your friend! Use clear and visually appealing slides, charts, and images to illustrate key concepts and make the information more memorable. Avoid dense blocks of text. Think visually.

Journalist: And what about the delivery itself?

Yulia Benzov: Delivery is crucial. Be enthusiastic and approachable! Your energy will be contagious. Maintain eye contact, use a friendly tone, and encourage questions throughout the presentation. Make it a two-way conversation, not just you talking at them.

Journalist: How can you ensure the information is retained?

Yulia Benzov: Interactive elements are key. Incorporate quizzes, polls, or small group activities to reinforce learning and keep the new hires engaged. This also allows them to apply what they've learned immediately.

Journalist: Any tips on making the content relevant?

Yulia Benzov: Absolutely. Connect the information to their specific roles and responsibilities. Explain how company policies and procedures directly impact their day-to-day work. This makes the information more relevant and helps them understand its importance.

Journalist: What about the overall atmosphere?

Yulia Benzov: Create a welcoming and supportive environment. Onboarding shouldn't feel like a formal lecture. Make it a positive and interactive experience where new hires feel comfortable asking questions and sharing their thoughts.

Journalist: Excellent advice, Ms. Benzov. Thank you for sharing your insights.

Yulia Benzov: You're welcome. Effective onboarding is an investment in the future of your company. By making the process engaging and informative, you set new hires up for success from the start.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: According to Yulia Benzov, what is a key element of keeping onboarding presentations engaging?
answers:
Making the presentations as long as possible to cover everything.

Using complex technical jargon to impress new hires.

Keeping the presentations concise and focused on essential information.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Yulia Benzov recommend using to make information more memorable?
answers:
Visual aids such as charts and images.

Dense blocks of text on slides. 

Long, uninterrupted lectures.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Yulia Benzov emphasize regarding the delivery of onboarding presentations?
answers:
Being enthusiastic, approachable, and encouraging questions.

Maintaining a formal and distant demeanor. 

Reading directly from a script to avoid mistakes.

params.text: Yulia Benzov is meeting with a new recruit at Strickland Food Group, Purchasing Officer Claire Williams. Please listen to the interaction and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Delivering Presentations – Meeting & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

Yulia Benzov: Hi Claire, welcome! I'm Yulia Benzov, HR Manager. How are you settling in?

Claire Williams: Hi Yulia, thanks! It's been great so far. Everyone's been very welcoming.

Yulia Benzov: That's wonderful to hear. Today, I wanted to walk you through the company's purchasing procedures. This is a crucial part of your role as Purchasing Officer.

Claire Williams: Great, I'm eager to learn.

Yulia Benzov: We've prepared a short presentation outlining the key steps involved in the purchasing process, from identifying needs to vendor selection and order fulfillment. We'll also cover our ethical sourcing guidelines and sustainability initiatives.

Claire Williams: Sounds good.

Yulia Benzov: As you can see, the first step is identifying the need for a particular product or service. This often comes from different departments within the company. Then, you'll need to get approval from the relevant budget holder.

Claire Williams: Okay, that makes sense. And what about vendor selection?

Yulia Benzov: We have a list of approved vendors that meet our quality and ethical standards. We encourage you to explore these options first. If you need to consider a new vendor, there's a specific process you'll need to follow, which we'll cover later. It involves submitting a vendor evaluation form.

Claire Williams: Got it. And what about sustainable purchasing? You mentioned that earlier.

Yulia Benzov: Sustainability is a top priority for Strickland Food Group. We're committed to sourcing materials and products that are environmentally friendly and ethically produced. We'll provide you with resources and training on how to identify and select sustainable vendors. We also have a sustainable purchasing checklist that you'll use for all purchases.

Claire Williams: That sounds great. I'm passionate about sustainability, so I'm glad to see that it's a focus here.

Yulia Benzov: Absolutely. We believe that ethical and sustainable practices are essential for our long-term success. Do you have any questions so far?

Claire Williams: Yes, a couple. What's the typical turnaround time for purchase orders? And who do I contact if I have a question about a specific vendor?

Yulia Benzov: The turnaround time usually depends on the vendor and the complexity of the order. We aim to process all purchase orders within three business days. If you have any questions about a specific vendor, you can contact our Vendor Relations team. Their contact details are in the handbook I gave you.

Claire Williams: Perfect. Thanks for clarifying everything. This presentation was very helpful.

Yulia Benzov: You're welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if you have any further questions as you get started. We're here to support you.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is the main topic of the presentation Yulia gives to Claire?
answers:
Purchasing procedures at Strickland Food Group 

Company benefits and perks

Employee code of conduct

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What is one of the key aspects of vendor selection mentioned by Yulia?
answers:
Prioritizing vendors that meet quality and ethical standards.

Choosing the cheapest vendor regardless of quality. 

Selecting vendors based on personal relationships.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Who should Claire contact if she has a question about a specific vendor?
answers:
The Vendor Relations team 

Yulia Benzov 

Her department manager

Xian Lee and Ahmed Lidneb bump into each other at a RH conference. Please listen to their conversation and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Delivering Presentations – Meeting & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

Xian Lee: Ahmed, it's good to catch you. I'm prepping for some new hire onboarding sessions next week and wanted to get your thoughts on effective presentations. You always seem to have such engaged new recruits at Warner Aerospace.

Ahmed Lidneb: Thanks, Xian. I appreciate that. I think the key is to remember your audience. New hires are often overwhelmed with information, so you need to make it digestible and relevant.

Xian Lee: Absolutely. I try to avoid information overload, but it's hard to know what to cut sometimes.

Ahmed Lidneb: I find it helpful to focus on the "why" behind the policies and procedures. Instead of just listing rules, explain why they exist and how they benefit the employee and the company. That makes it much more engaging and less like a lecture.

Xian Lee: That's a great point. Connecting it to their day-to-day work is essential. I try to give practical examples, but I could probably do more of that.

Ahmed Lidneb: Definitely. And don't underestimate the power of visuals. A well-designed slide deck can make a huge difference. Use images, charts, and even short videos to illustrate your points. Keep the text concise and easy to read.

Xian Lee: I've been trying to improve my slide decks. I tend to put too much text on them. I'll definitely work on that. What about interaction? How do you keep them engaged?

Ahmed Lidneb: Interaction is crucial! Don't just talk at them for hours. Break up the presentation with Q&A sessions, small group activities, or even short quizzes. It keeps them involved and helps reinforce the information.

Xian Lee: I like the quiz idea. It makes it a bit more fun too. I also try to incorporate icebreakers at the beginning to make people feel more comfortable.

Ahmed Lidneb: That's a good strategy. Creating a relaxed and welcoming atmosphere is so important. New hires are often nervous, so anything you can do to put them at ease will make the onboarding process much smoother.

Xian Lee: Thanks, This is all really helpful. I'll definitely incorporate some of these tips into my upcoming sessions.

Ahmed Lidneb: No problem. Good luck with your onboarding! Remember, it's all about creating a positive first impression and setting new hires up for success.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What key advice does Ahmed give Xian regarding the content of onboarding presentations?
answers:
Explain the "why" behind policies and procedures, connecting them to the employee's work. 

Focus on complex technical details to impress new hires. 

Keep the presentations as long as possible to cover all aspects of the company.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Ahmed suggest using to make presentations more visually appealing?
answers:
Images, charts, and short videos.

Dense blocks of text on slides. 

Only verbal explanations, avoiding visual aids altogether.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What does Ahmed emphasize regarding interaction during onboarding presentations?
answers:
Incorporating Q&A sessions, group activities, or quizzes. 

Avoiding any interaction to maintain a formal atmosphere. 

Limiting interaction to only the end of the presentation.

Delivering Presentations - Forum & Write
You are on an online forum where people are discussing how new employees are onboarded in their teams. Please read the posts and add to the discussion with a post of your own (around 60 words).

Rosa Gutierrez:
(Purchasing Officer at
Warner Aerospace)

Louisa Dawson:
(Marketing Team at
Strickland Food Group)

James Hinchcliffe:
(Accounts Manager at
Grant Consulting)

"In our purchasing team, we pair new hires with a senior team member for their first few weeks. This 'buddy system' is really effective. The buddy helps them navigate our procurement system, introduces them to key suppliers, and answers any questions, no matter how small. It makes the onboarding process much less daunting."

"Our marketing team takes a more project-based approach to onboarding. New hires are immediately involved in a small, manageable project. This allows them to learn by doing and contribute right away. We find this boosts their confidence and helps them quickly integrate into the team's workflow."

"At Grant Consulting, we believe in a structured onboarding program. New hires receive a detailed onboarding pack with all the essential information. We also have regular check-in meetings with them during their first month to address any concerns and ensure they're on track with their training and integration."

params.exportNotSupported: Export not supported on your device
params.label: How are new employees integrated into your team? Please write a post of around 60 words. (Remember to click ‘export text’ on the final page of the module so you can show this work to your teacher in the lesson).

params.text: Please listen to a conversation between two CEOs and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Addressing Questions – Conversation & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

James Warner: Caroline, I've been really impressed with how quickly your new hires at Strickland seem to get up to speed and embrace your company culture. We're always looking for ways to improve our onboarding process at Warner Aerospace.

Caroline Donald: Thanks, James. We've put a lot of effort into creating a comprehensive onboarding program. One thing we focus on is creating a culture of open communication right from the start.

James Warner: That's interesting. How do you do that in practice?

Caroline Donald: Well, firstly, we encourage new hires to ask questions – any questions at all – without feeling hesitant. We want them to feel comfortable voicing their concerns or uncertainties.

James Warner: That makes sense. We have a Q&A session at the end of our onboarding week, but perhaps we could be more proactive.

Caroline Donald: Exactly. We also assign each new hire a mentor from their team. This gives them a go-to person for any questions that might come up during their first few months.

James Warner: A mentor system... I like that idea. It provides more personalized support.

Caroline Donald: It really does. And it helps reinforce our company values. The mentor can share their own experiences and demonstrate how those values are reflected in their daily work.

James Warner: That's a great way to ensure alignment with company culture. We do have a code of conduct, but perhaps we need to go beyond just handing them a document.

Caroline Donald: Definitely. We also organize informal social events during the onboarding period. This helps new hires connect with their colleagues on a personal level and get a better sense of the company culture outside of the formal training sessions.

James Warner: That's a good point. We could definitely incorporate more social elements into our onboarding.

Caroline Donald: Ultimately, it's about making new hires feel welcome, supported, and valued. When they feel like they belong, they're more likely to embrace the company culture and contribute their best work.

James Warner: Thanks for the insights. I'm going to take these ideas back to my HR team and see how we can implement some of them at Warner Aerospace.

Caroline Donald: You're welcome. I'm always happy to share best practices. Onboarding is an ongoing process, and there's always room for improvement.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What is one of the key strategies Caroline Donald mentions for ensuring open communication with new hires?
answers:
Encouraging new hires to ask any questions without hesitation.

Limiting questions to the end of the onboarding week.

Discouraging questions to avoid disruptions.

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What support system does Strickland Food Group use to provide personalized guidance to new hires?
answers:
A mentor system where each new hire is paired with a colleague.

Mandatory overtime for new employees. 

Strict performance evaluations in the first week.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: Besides formal training, what other approach does Caroline Donald suggest for reinforcing company culture during onboarding?
answers:
Organizing informal social events to help new hires connect with colleagues.

Isolating new hires to focus on independent work.

Strictly enforcing dress code regulations.

params.text: Please listen to an extract of a conversation between a HR Manager and a new recruit and answer the questions:

params.audioNotSupported: Your browser does not support this audio

params.text: Addressing Questions – Meeting & Quiz
Dialogue Text:

Yulia Benzov: Hi Claire, how are you settling in? I wanted to check in and see if you have any questions about your onboarding or work contract.

Claire Williams: Hi Yulia, thanks. Things are going well, but I do have a couple of questions. I was looking over the contract, and I wasn't entirely clear about the probationary period.

Yulia Benzov: Absolutely. The probationary period at Strickland Food Group is three months. During this time, we'll be regularly reviewing your performance and providing feedback. It's a chance for both you and the company to ensure it's a good fit.

Claire Williams: Okay, that makes sense. And what happens after the probationary period?

Yulia Benzov: If your performance meets our expectations, your contract will automatically be confirmed, and you'll become a permanent employee. We'll have a formal review meeting towards the end of the three months to discuss your progress and answer any questions you have.

Claire Williams: That's good to know. I also had a question about the company's policy on professional development. I'm keen to continue learning and improving my skills.

Yulia Benzov: We encourage professional development at Strickland Food Group. We offer a range of training programs and workshops, and we also support employees who wish to pursue further education relevant to their roles. We have a dedicated budget for this, and we can discuss specific options that align with your career goals during your performance review.

Claire Williams: That sounds fantastic. I'm really interested in learning more about sustainable procurement practices.

Yulia Benzov: We can definitely explore that. We have some excellent resources on sustainable sourcing, and we can also connect you with some industry experts. We want to support you in developing your expertise in this area.

Claire Williams: That's great. I appreciate the company's commitment to both employee development and sustainability.

Yulia Benzov: It's important to us. We believe that investing in our employees is essential for our long-term success. Do you have any other questions about your contract or anything else?

Claire Williams: No, I think that covers everything for now. Thank you for clarifying everything.

Yulia Benzov: You're very welcome. Don't hesitate to reach out if any other questions come up. We're here to support you.

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: How long is the probationary period at Strickland Food Group?
answers:
Three months 

One month 

Six months

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What does Yulia say about professional development opportunities at Strickland Food Group?
answers:
The company offers a range of training programs and supports further education. 

They are not offered to new employees during their probationary period. 

Employees are responsible for funding their own professional development.

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What area of professional development is Claire particularly interested in?
answers:
Sustainable procurement practices 

Financial management 

Marketing strategies

params.text:
Yulia Benzov:
(HR Manager at
Strickland Food Group)

Claire Williams:
(New Recruit at
Strickland Food Group)
Addressing Questions - What Would You Say?
What would you say in the following situations? Please answer the following questions:

choices.question: Question 1 of 4: A new employee, David, asks you about the company's policy on flexible working hours. He mentions he has occasional childcare responsibilities. What would you say?
answers:
"I understand. Let's discuss your specific situation. We do have options for flexible working, such as staggered hours or compressed workweeks, depending on the role and team requirements”

"Flexible working is a complex issue, and we're still developing our policy. Just stick to the standard hours for now." 

"Let me direct you to the employee handbook. It has all the details on flexible working arrangements."

choices.question: Question 2 of 4: A new hire, Maria, is feeling overwhelmed by the amount of information presented during onboarding. She says she's worried she won't remember everything. What would you say?
answers:
"I understand it's a lot to take in. We have all the onboarding materials available online, so you can review them at your own pace. We also have a buddy system, so you can ask your buddy any questions you have”

"Don't worry, everyone feels that way. You'll pick it up as you go." 

"Just focus on the most important things for now. The rest will come later."

choices.question: Question 3 of 4: A new employee, Ben, asks you about opportunities for career advancement within the company. What would you say?
answers:
"That's a great question, Ben. We encourage our employees to grow and develop within the company. We have a career development program that includes training, mentorship, and internal job postings." 

"Just focus on your current role for now. You've only just started." 

"Career advancement is a long-term goal. We'll discuss that in your annual performance review."

choices.question: Question 4 of 4: A new employee, Sarah, expresses concern about a new company policy that she feels is unfair. What would you say?
answers:
"I understand your concern, Sarah. Could you explain what specifically you find unfair about it? " 

"The policy is the policy. There's nothing we can do about it." 

"Don't worry about it too much. You'll get used to it."

params.text: Addressing Questions – Forum & Quiz

You are on an online forum where new recruits are recounting their onboarding experiences.
Please read the posts and answer the following questions:

"My onboarding at Grant Consulting was really well-structured. I appreciated the clear schedule and the fact that they paired me with a senior consultant right away. Shadowing them for a week gave me real insight into how projects are managed here. The training sessions on internal systems were also very helpful. I feel much more confident going into my first client assignment."

Rakesh Chowdry:
(Consultant at
Grant Consulting)

Fatima Diouf:
(Engineer at
Warner Aerospace)

"I was a bit nervous starting at such a large company, but Warner Aerospace's onboarding process was very welcoming. The tour of the facilities was impressive, and I especially liked learning about the company's commitment to sustainability. Meeting my team and manager on the first day made me feel like I was already part of the group. I'm excited to contribute!"

Claire Williams:
(Purchasing Officer at
Strickland Food Group)

"Strickland Food Group's focus on ethical sourcing during onboarding was a big plus for me. I learned a lot about their sustainable procurement policies and how they work in practice. I also appreciated the chance to ask questions and clarify any doubts I had about my role and responsibilities. I feel well-prepared to start making a real contribution to the team."

choices.question: Question 1 of 3: What did Rakesh Chowdry find most helpful during his onboarding at Grant Consulting?
answers:
Shadowing a senior consultant and the training sessions 

The company's history and mission statement 

The office tour and meeting his team

choices.question: Question 2 of 3: What aspect of Warner Aerospace's onboarding did Fatima Diouf particularly appreciate?
answers:
The company's commitment to sustainability

The size of the company and its global reach 

The high salary and benefits package

choices.question: Question 3 of 3: What was a key takeaway for Claire Williams from her onboarding experience at Strickland Food Group?
answers:
Understanding the company's ethical sourcing policies 

Learning about the company's cafeteria and lunch options 

Getting to know the CEO and other senior executives

params.text: Module Summary Quiz
Let's see what you remember! Please complete this module summary quiz:

choices.question: Question 1 of 6: Which of the following is NOT a typical topic covered during employee onboarding?
answers:
Employee's personal financial investments 

Company policies and procedures 

Role and responsibilities

choices.question: Question 2 of 6: What is the purpose of an organizational chart (org chart)?
answers:
To visually represent the company's structure and reporting relationships.

To outline the company's financial performance.

To list employee birthdays and anniversaries.

choices.question: Question 3 of 6: What is a key strategy for delivering engaging onboarding presentations?
answers:
Keeping the presentations concise, focused, and visually appealing.

Using complex technical jargon to demonstrate expertise. 

Making the presentations as long as possible to cover every detail.

choices.question: Question 4 of 6: Which of the following is an effective way to address new hires' questions and concerns?
answers:
Actively listening, providing clear answers, and offering support.

Dismissing their questions as unimportant. 

Telling them to figure things out on their own.

choices.question: Question 5 of 6: What is the purpose of a probationary period?
answers:
To evaluate the employee's performance and suitability for the role.

To provide new employees with extra vacation time.

To determine the employee's salary and benefits package.

choices.question: Question 6 of 6: What is a "buddy system" in the context of onboarding?
answers:
Pairing new hires with a senior team member for guidance and support.

A system for assigning new hires to group projects.

A program for rewarding high-performing employees.
